thread.title: The Carl Frampton story: From a kid in a hotel in Portstewart to Las Vegas
thread.title_full: The Carl Frampton story: From a kid in a hotel in Portstewart to Las Vegas

title: The Carl Frampton story: From a kid in a hotel in Portstewart to Las Vegas
text:
GETTY Carl Frampton has an unbeaten record of 23 wins 
This weekend he headlines one of the sport’s most iconic venues in the MGM Grand hotel on the Las Vegas strip. 
Frampton, 29, defends the WBA featherweight title he took from Leo Santa Cruz last July in a much-anticipated rematch of their 2016 fight of the year contender at the MGM Grand Garden Arena. 
The Northern Irishman is now a two-weight world champion and was regarded globally as the best fighter of 2016. 
It has been an incredible journey since a seven-year-old from the Tigers Bay area of Belfast wearing Midland Boxing Club colours made his ring debut in the small town in Derry. 
“I will probably reflect on it more when my career is over,” said Frampton. 
“It is a big deal when you think of it and where I came from. A hotel in Portstewart to here. 
“A lot has happened since I had my first fight and it is hard to believe really. It makes you proud. 
“Just to see your name up in lights in Vegas, I never really believed this could happen when I turned professional. 
“I would have been happy to have won a world title and that to be it but as my career has progressed I feel like I’m making new goals and targets all the time.” 
There was no victory that night against his opponent from Scorpion Boxing Club as both were under the age of 11 and barely over 20kg so could not compete competitively. 
But there have been plenty of victories since then. 
Frampton had a successful amateur career in Ireland before being spotted by mentor and manager Barry McGuigan at the 2007 EU amateur boxing championships. 
He would turn professional in 2009 with McGuigan and they have not taken a step back since. 
Now with an unbeaten record of 23 wins, Frampton looks to defend the title once held by his mentor on the biggest stage he has ever been on and is arguably the best of the UK’s 13 reigning world champions. 
The Belfast man has been in Las Vegas for the last three weeks acclimatising to the time difference and conditions, but it has also given him a chance to see his name plastered down the side of the MGM Grand on his walks down the Strip. Boxing WAGS: The babes backing their boxer men Thursday, 4th January 2018 Let’s take a look at the top hot pictures of boxing WAGs you need to see 1 / 9 Getty/Instagram Amir Khan – Faryal Makhdoom 
There is also a huge screen showing clips of Frampton in action in Sin City. This is a long way from the picturesque seaside town of Portstewart. 
The MGM Grand Garden Arena was once the home of Floyd Mayweather Jnr and hosted some of the biggest fights in the sport’s recent history, including the American’s clash with Manny Pacquiao. 
Frampton used to stay up overnight in his Tigers Bay to watch the likes of Mike Tyson and his hero and compatriot Wayne McCullough, Northern Ireland’s last world champion before him, in action. 
But dreams of one day being the star in the city famous for gambling never entered his head with aspirations closer to home and in a different sport. 
“When I was a kid and watched the big fights I never really thought ‘I would love that to be me’,” he said. 
“I probably never believed that it would have been me if I’m being honest. 
“I was more dreaming about playing football for the Crues (Crusaders FC) or something like that. 
“Just to be here in this position now and to top the bill with the calibre of fighter I am facing is great.” 
Frampton believes there will be around 4,000 making the trip from the UK and Ireland to watch him in action this weekend. 
And he plans to make it a night to remember not just for them but for himself. 
“You can’t dwell on it too much now,” he added. 
“You have to wait until you hang up the gloves to reflect on it. 
“I’ll probably be that wee man sitting in the bar telling everyone about the time I topped the bill in Vegas. 
“It makes me proud and very honoured to do it. It has been a long road, but I feel like I deserve to be here.” Related articles
